>> 
>> I think this is a neat idea (no=
 pun) but I'm not sure that it
>> ultimately
>> helps.  
>> ...
>> If we're=
 then
>> evaluating them as a group, aren't we talking about basically one
=
>> individual and therefor the same complexity (possibly greater)?
> 
> Tha=
t's true in a way.  I don't really know which is slower, evolving
> multipl=
e sets of similar nets or evolving one monolithic net and using
> separate =
boolean input nodes (or negative values to the optional
> nodes) to indicat=
e when nodes should be ignored.  For example, you
> would need betting info=
rmation about the flop and turn on the river,
> but would need some way to =
indicate that the information is no longer
> relevant on the earlier rounds=
.
> 
> I tend to think evolving separate networks is the better approach
> =
because it will tell us more about the game itself.  As networks grow
> in =
size and complexity, the ability to understand the "why" behind
> their str=
ucture diminishes.
>  
>> I'm guessing a lot of these tournaments would hav=
e to be played.  In
> which
>> case, it is insufficient to say "a fraction =
of a second".  I am
> forced to
>> ask, which fraction?
>> 
> 
> I have a f=
ramework which I have used already which is not in any way
> as fast as pok=
er eval (I wrote it before finding poker eval).  This is
> what I used to d=
o my simulations.
> 
> I was able to calculate all the stats I mentioned pr=
eviously in my
> past experiments (using exhaustive evaluation of all possi=
ble hands to
> find your overall hand rank).  A session would consist of a =
6 handed
> game of limit hold em which lasted 1000 hands.  Each bot would p=
lay a
> session against a randomly selected group of 5 other bots.  I used =
a
> fixed size population of 50 bots, (i.e., 50,000 hands per generation).
=
>  The total time for evaluating 1 generation, performing selection and
> m=
utation, and serializing the bots to file (in case of a system crash)
> usi=
ng a AMD 3500+ was about 40 seconds on average.
> 
> I was able to run seve=
ral hundred generations overnight and wake up to
> lovely and horrible resu=
lts. :)
>  
>> But I agree parallelizing it would be hella cool.
>>

 think this is going to be my first step.  It will certainly help to

liarize myself with the details of NEAT.
